          OpenAI releases "Strawberry" -01 preview model focused on reasoning by incorporating an Ai agent into multi-step complex task execution. 

Great article from Ethan Mollick with experiments and results. He writes: 
"Using o1-preview means confronting a paradigm change in AI. Planning is a form of agency, where the AI arrives at conclusions about how to solve a problem on its own, without our help." 

Incorporating Ai agents is an inevitable step in the evolution of LLMs and Generative Ai.  We will indeed be facing some interesting conversations on the future of work as Ai continues to take on more and more complex activities.

          Here are the top 3 most promising startup ideas I identified from the interview with John Schulman (OpenAI) by Dwarkesh Patel.

1.  AI-powered coding assistant that can understand high-level instructions, write code, test it, and iterate to complete entire coding projects with minimal human involvement. e.g. Devin, Github Co-pilot

2. AI system that can read and understand all the scientific literature in a field, sift through data, and help accelerate research by assisting human scientists and making new discoveries. e.g. Iris.ai

3. AI assistant that works alongside a human on their computer, understands the full context of the project they are working on, proactively makes suggestions, and performs work in the background. e.g. Adept AI

          Optimize for 🚀 Bio Cores First, Silicon 🤖 Cores Second

David Heinemeier Hansson makes a compelling case: prioritize human programmers (bio cores) over computer processing power (silicon cores).

Here’s why it matters:
👉 Investing in programmer efficiency is far more valuable than solely optimizing for computer speed. 
👉 Human labor costs far exceed computing costs. Boosting human productivity should be the main focus. 
👉 In the age of AI and high-level programming languages, the bio cores drive your real gains.

Bottom line: Make your programmers more productive, and watch your team (and tech) thrive.

Read the full article here:  https://lnkd.in/gK8HEGtk

Impact on Industry

• Drug discovery timelines shortened from years to weeks.

Ksenia Se
        
              
          François Chollet introduced the ARC benchmark to test AI on tasks that require core, fundamental knowledge rather than memorization. 
Here is a summary of Dwarkesh Patel's conversation with François Chollet on why LLMs won’t lead to AGI and why ARC benchmark is crucial:

▪️ Purpose of the ARC benchmark:

It is designed to assess whether AI can handle tasks that require a basic, fundamental understanding of concepts, such as elementary physics and object recognition. 
The tasks in ARC are novel, demanding genuine reasoning rather than recall. 

▪️ Critique of scaling LLMs:

Chollet argues that simply increasing the size of LLMs by feeding them more data doesn't boost true intelligence.
This scaling up enhances models' ability to interpolate between known data points, which is basically a sophisticated pattern matching.

▪️ Intelligence vs. memorization: 

True intelligence is the ability to encounter a new problem and devise a solution without prior experience.
In contrast, current AI systems often rely on 'memorizing' solutions from numerous similar training examples. 

▪️ The $1 million ARC Prize: 

To motivate advancements towards genuine AI reasoning capabilities, @fchollet and @mikeknoop have announced a million-dollar prize for the team that first achieves a score of 85% on the ARC benchmark. This score marks the average human performance

▪️ Concerns over AI research concentration: 

Collet claims that corporations like OpenAI have monopolized AI research and hindered open innovation by restricting access to their latest findings. This centralization is believed to slow down broader AI progress for several years.

▪️ Future of AI development:

For AI to achieve human-like general intelligence, models need to go beyond mere data interpolation. This includes development of methods for discrete program synthesis and search that can generalize across diverse tasks with minimal data.

Here's the full video of the conversation. It's worth watching:
https://lnkd.in/e6Bczav8

Vedant Nair
        
              
          Benjamin Bolte from K-Scale Labs just posted his 'Robotics Predictions for 2025' containing some hot takes 🦾🔥

By the end of 2025....

1. Humanoid hardware is commoditized

- Hardware components will converge, but robot designs will remain different
- Actuators no longer differentiators; industry moves towards open-source like MIT Cheetah
- BOM for a humanoid will come down to a shocking <$8k!

Question: What happens to incumbents like Telsa, Figure, 1X, Apptronik, etc., who have spent billions of $ in R&D to create robots with a $50 - $150k BOM?

2. No ChatGPT moment for robotics

-  A LOT of data (millions of hours) is needed to train a general-purpose robotics model
- Language + multi-modal models will not be able to control a robot sufficiently
- Progress will be incremental rather than spiky

Question: If building a robot for a domain and bootstrapping to generality is a losing strategy, what's a better one?

3. More than half of humanoids will be sold to consumers

- The 'killer apps' will be speech and vision
- Traditional SLAs for business customers will force robotics teams away from building good generalist models
- "Robotics companies will start looking more like SV tech companies, caring about user engagement and retention."

Question: What are the 'killer' consumer use cases that will drive this adoption? What are the jobs to be done?

Link to the full blog in the comments. What are your thoughts?

Bahgat Ahmed
        
              
          Many are fixated on prompt engineering, especially those using no-code AI tools while overlooking the power of fine-tuning.

Remember: Each layer of abstraction simplifies tasks but limits customization. This works well for proofs of concept or simple applications. However, more complex projects often demand extensive customization.

Depth of knowledge truly sets you apart. Loving your craft often stems from this depth – the more you can customize, the more power you have.

While prompt engineering and no-code solutions are great starting points, don't forget that fine-tuning can unlock deeper AI capabilities for sophisticated applications.

Prompt Engineering is still useful for many applications but remember when to use which to avoid limiting yourself.

#AI #MachineLearning #PromptEngineering #Finetuning

Amine Aouragh
        
              
          "we don't have anything that truly breaks the input down into tokens unfortunately."

That's what a guy from the Gemini team told me the other day when I was presenting my idea of building a tokenizer for Gemini

2 weeks later I thought about a feature that wasn't even supposed to be there or I should say never seriously considered building. 

It was supposed to be a tokenizer and that's it.

But then I thought how to make something the other one doesn't have? 

*cough* OpenAI *cough*

Have you ever wondered how much you're actually spending when using AI models like Gemini API for example? 🤔 

AI token usage is a key metric that determines the cost of interacting with these models, yet it’s often overlooked or misunderstood by developers and businesses alike.

That’s why I am integrating a Token Usage Cost Calculator—a simple yet powerful feature to the tokenizer I'm building for Gemini:

✅ Instantly calculate token usage based on your text prompts.

You don't have to calculate that by hand. 

✅ Predict the cost of using specific AI models depending on their input/output pricing tiers.

For now the tool I'm building would only show you the input pricing because you insert/paste aka "input" a text/prompt into the tool.

✅ Help users and businesses optimize their budget and avoid surprises when scaling AI usage.

So I created a JSON file with relevant pricing information I got from https://lnkd.in/es4U_B9P about each Gemini model.

And whenever the user inserts a text prompt and selects a Gemini model they will get: 

✅Token count 
✅Token usage cost

Isn't that nice?

#ml #gemini #ai #google #devs

Jean Lee
        
              
          Is Devin the AI Stealing Your Software Engineering Job? Don't Panic!
Seeing headlines about Devin, the "first AI software engineer," might have you sweating.
Let's address the AI in the room: will it replace us?
Here's the truth: Take the Twitter hype machine with a grain of salt.

I’ve talked about exponential growth! Meaning, you do want to look out for the newest updates in tech. BUT you gotta learn to analyze news and tweets.
According to the IMF’s recent report, AI will impact all industries, not just ours. Repetitive tasks like accounting or cashiering are more likely to see automation first.
Coding is a fantastic path. If you can think of a better one, hit the comments below! In the meantime, keep learning and growing as an engineer.

P.S. Looking for guidance in your engineering journey? Follow me! 🔔 Follow me for more career advice: https://lnkd.in/gQGpx3XB
